Headline: Product Leader | Driving Product Innovation (0->1, Growth, AI/ML , enterprise scale)
Comment:
Agreed a 100%.  Getting fit and healthy is the only way out. 
The type of programs that need to be done by parents to stay healthy and fit is quite different from the traditional S&C, HIIT , weight loss driven programs. 

Transformation.Studio:   We're experimenting with programming for parents specifically. Focussing on foundations more than high performance. 
With dipping energy levels, parents need workouts and nutrition that improve recovery and help them get the most out of their days.   

Curious to see/learn how parents stay fit, especially the ones who are starting from a low baseline level of fitness.

Headline: Ex-Founder | Brand & Category Strategy | Consumer Insight | Fractional EIR | Women √ó Work | Community Builder
Comment:
I agree so wholeheartedly. 6 months ago I felt this so acutely. 

When you are not fit or healthy. It has so much spillover on so many aspects of your life. 

I have literally spent the last 6 months carving a fitter self (mentally and physically) so that I am a capable parent, partner, employee, boss..

Lost 30kgs, started therapy, going regularly to the gym. Learned some lifelong skills w.r.t food, fixed sleep, started meditation. Focused on building extendable rhythms than habits.

I literally feel like a different human being and my kids can most definitely tell that I enjoy spending time with them and not doing it to check off a box.

It is 1 million % worth it.

Headline: TEDx Speaker, IRONMAN, LISTENER, PhD Scholar, COACH, Sales & Strategy Leader, Author,
Comment:
Not sure how old your child is now Dilip. 

But guess how underrated is to be a teen. Come home to a parent who has no clue how demanding the teachers are. How long the test was. How tiring the PE class was. How many periods they ahve to attend. All that the parents expect is for the smile, act jolly, cuddle up and act as if they have the perfect day at school everyday!!

You still muster your courage and try not reflect all this and when your dad asks you how was your day, you muster up the courage to say 'fine' and a half smile, keen to get on with the dinner.
